Notes: Extremely hardy crop that requires little inputs. Exhibits a wide range of phenotypic variation, including a lots of variation in flowering and fruiting times. Self-pollinating. Tolerates soils with low fertility, but not in successive years. Commercial varieties of sesame require 90 to 120 frost-free days. Good drainage is very important. Most varieties are divided into shattering and non-shattering categories.

_uses.Notes: The seeds of S. indicum are a major international food product. They have numerous health benefits and are high in a number of minerals. They are commonly roasted, ground into flour, made into the paste "tahini" and are included in a large number of both sweet and savory food products. The leaves are sometimes smoked as a tobacco substitute. The stem ash is high in minerals and can be used as a nutritional salt. The leaves can be eaten raw or cooked. 70% of sesame yields go towards the production of sesame oil. It is a highly stable oil that resists rancidity due to its antioxidant content. It is eaten raw and for cooking and flavoring.
Sesame seeds are used in perfumes in Africa and parts of the flowers are used for cologne.
Sesame oil is used in soap and various cosmetic products. It has beneficial uses for the skin.
Numerous medicinal uses, both in ethnobotanical medicine and modern pharmaceuticals.
The dry plant stalks can be used as fuel. Additionally, research has found sesame oil to be a promising biofuel.
